title: Im getting realy sick of seeing Yasuo in every single damn game
body: Seriously, I think my last 10 games has had one in every single game

> [{quoted}](name=Avedecus,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=1EMmlEki,comment-id=0005000000000002,timestamp=2015-10-21T02:10:44.445+0000)

> Do you actually try to play against him, or do you try to play like you're facing a regular midlaner and then get upset when it doesn't work?

the thing is that you are outlying yas as "not a regular midlaner"  which is an inherent problem.

You have to strategize. Wait out his shield. Bait his wind wall. Don't go in if he has his tornado up. 

You know who has a kit that is perfect against Yasuo? Akali. 

The challenge there is not being so far behind in farm by 6 that he does not have to fear you. He farms better and can zone you, so you have to freeze the lane just outside your tower and play passive. If you stay within 70-75% of his farm you will win lane (ignoring jungle interference).

***You have to strategize.*** 
Agreed
***Wait out his shield.*** 
You can't really "wait" out his shield, unless you mean wait for it to deplete after hitting him.
**Do you mean harass out his shield?**
Problem is a lot of mages are mana gated. Most long range abilities are skill shots which he easily dashes out of. Most targeted and AoE skills are close to Yas' engagement range. Same applies to AA's. Heaven forbid you're *near* your minions, which increases Yas' engagement range significantly. It makes Harassing him incredibly difficult.
***Bait his wind wall.*** 
It's hard to bait a good Yas. The wind wall acts as an "oh shit" button. And he most likely won't use it unless you've already shown commitment.
***Don't go in if he has his tornado up. ***
At lvl 1, steel tempest has a 4 second cooldown. It holds stacks for 10 seconds. That means he can effectively zone you for 10 seconds just by existing, with a 12 second CD. **At level 1.** Tempest gets 1.86% CDR per level from Yas's innate atk spd per level. That means the innate CD is 3.628 at level 6; a 10.884 second CD between zoning periods. Almost half your time spent in lane is effectively zoned by your recommendation. And I haven't even counted items yet!

***You know who has a kit that is perfect against Yasuo? Akali. ***
Counter-*picks*, while a valid matrix for balance, do not make up for counter-*play*. And Riot has stated multiple times they don't want to see match-ups decided by champ select.

***The challenge there is not being so far behind in farm by 6 that he does not have to fear you.***
So you beat him by [almost] matching his farm? Ok, that's fair. We're going with the assassin mentality.
***He farms better and can zone you,***
. . . *{face palm}* 
***so you have to freeze the lane just outside your tower and play passive.***
Ok. So I just have to freeze lane and play passively against an assassin that farms better than me and has good zoning (and is also resistant to harass). [sarcasm]Nothing wrong with this picture.[/sarcasm]
*** If you stay within 70-75% of his farm you will win lane (ignoring jungle interference).***
Being behind in CS isn't "winning" lane. At best, it's "holding" lane. This works fine for champs like Shen, Xerath, and Diana who can alter their play to compensate for reduced gold going into the mid game. But for others like Veriger, Viktor, Vel'koz, that gimped income can create a huge deficit. 

And let's not forget, Yasuo (a "hyper carry" according to Riot) has early power spikes. His first one coming at 2500 gold (static Shiv), and the second at 6300 (Infinity Edge). That means he's getting his first major power spike while most mages are just solving their mana problems (Morello-2300, Rod of Ages-2700, Archangel's-3000) or finishing their defense items (Iceborn Gauntlet-2850, Zhonya's-3000, Rod of Ages-2700, Rylai's-3000).

-----------------------------

Don't get me wrong. I'm not calling him OP. I'm also not saying he has *no* counter-play. But Yas' kit allows him to bypass his own weaknesses. He's squishy but has a low CD shield and his windall. He's short ranged but his high mobility. He's melee but with a long range hard CC zoning tool and [ult] initiation. He has to multi-hit minions with his Q, but has a long grace period and low CD to bypass mistakes. His ult requires a ~~knock-up~~ displacement, which he has on a 12 second minimal cooldown.
He has tons of safety nets built into his kt in case he makes a mistake. But he punishes enemies incomparably hard for making *any*.

This is not even a valid suggestion. Akali can be shop countered by either buying a pink ward, or upgrading your trinket into a pink ward totem. Her entire kit revolves around being able to manipulate windows in between her Q cool downs. Throw a Q, twilight shroud, wait for cd, R, auto, E, auto, Q again back into shroud. 

Pink ward > Akali.

Maybe if he has a dedicated team, but not really. Its your fault if you feel you need to throw your entire combo into his wind wall or you want to proc his shield with your ultimate.

I mean honestly people, is it Yasuo or is it you guys' inability to adept?

Its either "throw your combo out and hope he doesnt wall it" or "lose all kill pressure in lane when playing certain champions". 

When playing certain champions like Lux, its more about Yasuo making a mistake rather than any good play on your part. And while you can generally say "a counter can counter you. big deal", other counters can be manageable through outplaying the mechanics of the champion - like Zed, save your Q for when his ult animation lands behind you, Talon/Kat after they use their E to get behind you, or with Leblanc line up your Q toward her return pad.

Never said it made him tanky, not once did I make that claim, just look up and you'll see "makes him less squishy then most AD caster types."

Also the current Yasuo playstyle and item builds make him more of an AD caster then an assassin or fighter, his Q being his main source of damage for most the game and that being an AD ability.  AD casters are those who deal damage with their abilities and build AD items, like Yasuo for most the game.

The BotRK build makes him more of a fighter and the full crit burst build makes him more of an assassin, currently the main builds make him more of an AD caster.  That's why I said "AD caster TYPES," in that he can be many different things based on his items mainly due to how overloaded his kit is in general.
And I'm getting sick of ppl downvoting anything that contains "Yasuo" in it without shouting about how he is "bad, OP, overloaded, etc."

Obviously the champion needs to be viable if people are going to play it. You want to know the real reason Yasuo dropped off? Pros stopped playing him and everyone was convinced he was terrible. The meta was horrible to him for a very long time. Suddenly, the meta shifts, Yasuo is in favor again, pros start playing him again, and all the Yasuo players come out of the woodwork. I've been maining Yasuo since before he was gutted in 4.18. The only buff he got that was really substantial was in 4.21. Everything he's gotten since then has had little to no impact on his overall strength as a champion. You know what makes Yasuo look good though? Mid lane mages like Veigar, Lux, and Ahri being the dominant meta picks and adcs like Vayne and Jinx being the dominant adcs. This is an extremely favorable meta for Yasuo and he doesn't deserve to be nerfed because he's strong in the 1 meta that asssassins don't dominate mid lane. When champions like Zed, Fizz, Akali, and Cho start showing up mid again, Yasuo will start to disappear again. But in a meta where Lux, Veigar, and Ahri are the 3 most played mid laners, Yasuo isn't going anywhere.
So people are playing him because he's strong, and not because he's fun or fun doesn't matter unless the champ is already viable (strong). Are you trying to agree with me?

He's seeing a lot of play because:

1. He's fun to play.
2. He counters the strongest and most popular meta midlaners.
3. His counters are pretty uncommon at this time.
4. Pros have picked him up and shown he's worth picking again.

It's not an either or scenario. He's really enjoyable to play, the pros are inspiring other people to play him, and his matchups on average are probably the most favorable they've ever been. That doesn't seem too hard to understand.

You said that for a champ to be played, he needs to be viable. Points 2-4 reflect this.

Fun is merely a multiplier at best or completely irrelevant to popularity at worst. 

Point 1 by itself is not nearly a good enough reason to play Yasuo, as shown by the stats when he was considered trash.

tl;dr Yasuo and other "fun" champs are just as forgettable if they don't have stats coming from nowhere/favourable meta.
